theorem
fixes a b c :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat"

a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Shown below are rows 1, 2, and 3 of Pascal's triangle.

\[
\begin{array}{ccccccc}
& & 1 & & 1 & & \\
& 1 & & 2 & & 1 & \\
1 & & 3 & & 3 & & 1
\end{array}
\]Let $(a_i),$ $(b_i),$ $(c_i)$ be the sequence, from left to right, of elements in the 2005th, 2006th, and 2007th rows, respectively, with the leftmost element occurring at $i = 0.$  Compute
\[\sum_{i = 0}^{2006} \frac{b_i}{c_i} - \sum_{i = 0}^{2005} \frac{a_i}{b_i}.\] The final Answer is \frac{1}{2}
 ### Proof
 More generally, suppose $(a_i),$ $(b_i),$ $(c_i)$ represent the entries in rows $n - 1,$ $n,$ $n + 1$ of Pascal's triangle. Then \[a_i = \binom{n - 1}{i}, \ b_i = \binom{n}{i}, \ c_i = \binom{n + 1}{i},\]so
 \begin{align} \frac{a_i}{b_i} &= \frac{\binom{n - 1}{i}}{\binom{n}{i}} \\ &= \frac{\frac{(n - 1)!}{i! (n - i - 1)!}}{\frac{n!}{i! (n - i)!}} \\ &= \frac{(n - 1)! (n - i)!}{n! (n - i - 1)!} \\ &= \frac{n - i}{n} \\

 \end{align}Likewise, \[\frac{b_i}{c_i} = 1 - \frac{i}{n + 1},\]and \[\sum_{i = 0}^n \frac{b_i}{c_i} = \frac{n + 2}{2}.\]Hence, \[\sum_{i = 0}^n \frac{b_i}{c_i} - \sum_{i = 0}^{n - 1} \frac{a_i}{b_i} = \frac{n + 2}{2} - \frac{n + 1}{2} = \boxed{\frac{1}{2}}.\]
 *)

a_7.formal problem:
theorem
fixes a b c :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> i \<in> {0..2006}. b i = binomial 2006 i"
and h1 : "\<forall> i \<in> {0..2007}. c i = binomial 2007 i"
and h2 : "\<forall> i \<in> {0..2005}. a i = binomial 2005 i"
shows  "(\<Sum> i \<in> {0..2006}. real (b i) / real (c i)) - (\<Sum> i \<in> {0..2005}. real (a i) / real (b i)) = 1/2"
a_7.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Shown below are rows 1, 2, and 3 of Pascal's triangle.

\[
\begin{array}{ccccccc}
& & 1 & & 1 & & \\
& 1 & & 2 & & 1 & \\
1 & & 3 & & 3 & & 1
\end{array}
\]Let $(a_i),$ $(b_i),$ $(c_i)$ be the sequence, from left to right, of elements in the 2005th, 2006th, and 2007th rows, respectively, with the leftmost element occurring at $i = 0.$  Compute
\[\sum_{i = 0}^{2006} \frac{b_i}{c_i} - \sum_{i = 0}^{2005} \frac{a_i}{b_i}.\] The final Answer is \frac{1}{2}
 ### Proof
 More generally, suppose $(a_i),$ $(b_i),$ $(c_i)$ represent the entries in rows $n - 1,$ $n,$ $n + 1$ of Pascal's triangle. Then \[a_i = \binom{n - 1}{i}, \ b_i = \binom{n}{i}, \ c_i = \binom{n + 1}{i},\]so
 \begin{align} \frac{a_i}{b_i} &= \frac{\binom{n - 1}{i}}{\binom{n}{i}} \\ &= \frac{\frac{(n - 1)!}{i! (n - i - 1)!}}{\frac{n!}{i! (n - i)!}} \\ &= \frac{(n - 1)! (n - i)!}{n! (n - i - 1)!} \\ &= \frac{n - i}{n} \\
 &= 1 - \frac{i}{n}. \end{align}Hence, \begin{align} \sum_{i = 0}^{n - 1} \frac{a_i}{b_i} &= \sum_{i = 0}^{n - 1} \left( 1 - \frac{i}{n} \right) \\ &= n - \frac{(n - 1)n/2}{n} \\ &= n - \frac{n - 1}{2} = \frac{n + 1}{2}.
 \end{align}Likewise, \[\frac{b_i}{c_i} = 1 - \frac{i}{n + 1},\]and \[\sum_{i = 0}^n \frac{b_i}{c_i} = \frac{n + 2}{2}.\]Hence, \[\sum_{i = 0}^n \frac{b_i}{c_i} - \sum_{i = 0}^{n - 1} \frac{a_i}{b_i} = \frac{n + 2}{2} - \frac{n + 1}{2} = \boxed{\frac{1}{2}}.\]
 *)
